instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> question
threads.message:
I've got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which has charging / power issues. Had damage to <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> area - shorted pins 23&24 17&18 - after some diagnosis removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and shorts have gone away.
Problem is i've only got <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor boards and the <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> seems to have different pin placement. Does anyone know of any other boards that this chip exists on ?
Thanks!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> question
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>,3435,3462.
If <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is dead also replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> question
threads.message: Thanks Duke, i only have the  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> schematic so i couldn't search all my PDF's for the chip number, that's saved me a lot of time! ( i knew that the were ram differences between 3537 and 3476 but didn't know about the <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>) - yes <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> got changed too - pins 23&24 were burnt out and <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> had shorted to ground. Its now charging and ready for final testing. Please mark as solved.
